 - 1 - TECHNICAL ANNEX BANKING, ENTERPRISE AND LEGAL TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CREDIT I. BACKGROUND 1. Over the past six years, Mongolia has made considerable progress in transforming its economy into a market system. The country was plunged into economic turmoil in 1990 when the collapsing Soviet Union withdrew its subsidies, and the CMEA trading system disintegrated. Within months, Mongolia lost 35 percent of its GDP and 95 percent of its export markets. In response, the Government embarked on a program of economic stabilization and structural reform, and implemented an impressive range of measures to expand the scope of market transactions. These included price and trade liberalization, a mass privatization program, establishment of a two-tier banking system, and enactment of new laws and regulations favorable to private economic participation. 2. After four years of decline, Mongolia succeeded in reducing inflation and restoring economic growth. The growth was led by copper exports and increased agroindustry and service sector activities. Mongolia achieved 2.5 percent GDP growth in 1994, and a further 6.3 percent growth in 1995. Lower copper prices, however, disrupted growth in 1996, and the estimated GDP growth rate for 1996 is 2.6 percent. Inflation, which reached 325 percent in 1993 fell to 53 percent by the end of 1995, and remained at that level in 1996. During 1996, the Mongolian economy was hit by a succession of adverse developments that reversed some of the progress painstakingly made over the past years. Much of Mongolia's recent economic developments were the result of terms of trade shocks. A 25 percent decline in world copper prices in 1996, a 10 percent fall in cashmere prices, and further increases in world petroleum prices', induced a cost to the Mongolian economy equivalent to 10.3 percent of GDP in 1996, compared to a windfall gain of 8 percent in 1995. Extensive forest and steppe fires in April 1996 resulted in lower agricultural supplies and exports. While the agriculture exports and the copper, cashmere and petroleum terms of trade problems are likely to self-correct, the problems in the financial and enterprise sectors pose a longer-term threat to stabilization and growth. 3. Current Status of the Banking Sector. Mongolia saw a major erosion of public confidence in the banking system in 1996, with the collapse of a small private bank and the closure of two large banks that held approximately 50 percent of total deposits in the country. On December 13, 1996, the Government successfully closed two large insolvent banks. The 1996 banking crisis poses severe implications for inflation, financial control, and growth in the real sector. The authorities will have to further resolve the banking crisis and consistently implement strict macroeconomic policies to restore stability. iThe copper sector accounts for a quarter of GDP, half of export earnings, and about a third of overall tax receipts. Cashmere is the second leading export item, accounting for about 15 percent of export receipts. Petroleum and petroleum products account for 20 percent of its imports.
 - 2 - TECHNICAL ANNEX Mongolia's commercial banks are unable to offer effective financial intermediation due to a combination of factors: a legacy of government intervention in credit allocation, poor commercial banking skills, non-creditworthy borrowers and weak management. The banking sector as a whole has become insolvent and illiquid. Many of its largest enterprise clients consistently fail to service their debts. All banks have become heavily burdened with bad debt, and in desperate need of relief from this debt in order to survive. Loan recovery, including debt workout and financial restructuring of distressed enterprises, as appropriate, is therefore a prerequisite for building a healthy banking system. A radical bank restructuring and loan recovery strategy has been developed by the Mongolian authorities, in conjunction with the IMF, ADB and IDA, in response to the crisis. 4. Current Status of the Enterprise Sector. Structural reforms are needed to enhance the credibility of stabilization, and to spur growth by increasing productivity of the real sector. Mongolia's public and privatized enterprises face a variety of problems in conducting business, ranging from liquidity shortages and limited access to long-term credit, to diminishing markets and acute skills shortages at the micro-level. The Government's proposes to implement a medium-term enterprise reform agenda focusing on general hardening of budget constraints for enterprises, developing enterprise infrastructure and management skills, and accelerating the ongoing cash privatization program. 5. The Legal Environment. Progress in banking and enterprise reform relies heavily on the existence of a transparent legal framework, one which enjoys public confidence. Rules of the game for economic activity (concerning property rights, entry and exit of business vehicles, transactions, competition and dispute settlement) should be clear on paper and implemented in practice by institutions equipped in human and material terms to discharge their responsibilities. Since 1991, Mongolia has enacted an impressive set of laws and regulations related to the operation of the emerging market economy. However, the application of the new laws and regulations and their interpretation by the courts remain problematic, largely because of inadequate institutional capacity. As a result, banks and enterprises are seriously hampered by difficulties in such areas as contract enforcement (including loan collection), secured transactions, and the failure of bankruptcy procedures. Whilst legislative reform continues at full speed, Mongolia will, in view of enforcement problems highlighted above, have to focus increasingly on the difficult task of making its laws work in practice. This will require substantial and long term investments in support institutions like the judiciary, ministry of justice, property registries and legal education, as well as the dissemination of legal information (including legislation and case law). II. PROJECT OBJECTIVES 6. The purpose of the Project is to facilitate the implementation of key components of the Government's reform program in the banking and enterprise sectors, and to foster a legal environment which supports financial intermediation. The primary focus of all the proposed interventions is to develop effective and standardized procedures for default resolution, debt workout and loan collection, and to support bank-led restructuring of
 - 3 - TECHNICAL ANNEX distressed enterprises. This will create a valuable demonstration effect. The Government's policy reforms in these sectors are being supported by IDA's proposed Banking and Enterprise Sector Adjustment Credit (BESAC), and the Asian Development Bank's Financial Sector Program Loan (FSPL). Both of these projects are scheduled to become effective in early 1997. BELTAC will support the core institutions executing the policy reforms over the short term. The Project is also designed to promote longer-term institutional and technical skills development, so that the programs implemented under the BESAC may be sustained. BELTAC will provide advisory support, training, and where appropriate, materials and equipment for the Trade and Development Bank (T&D bank), a newly-established Debt Workout Unit (DWJU) in T&D bank, the State Property Committee (SPC), participating enterprises, MOJ, the judiciary and other legal support institutions. Coordination with Other Donors 7. The Project design takes into account completed, ongoing and proposed technical assistance activities financed by other donors. These are summarized in Annex I The importance of systematic and continuous donor coordination is one of the key lessons learned in project development in Mongolia. Moreover, aid coordination and efficient external resource allocation are priorities for the new Government. Several donor organizations, including NGOs, are currently active in the areas of banking, enterprise and legal reform, most notably: - IMF: assistance to the Ministry of Finance and Bank of Mongolia in macroeconomic management, fiscal and monetary policy, central bank supervision, accounting and settlement, and payment systems; * ADB: central bank supervision, commercial bank restructuring, equipment upgrading and staff training, bank and enterprise accountancy development, privatization support, legal reform including banking legislation and training of legal professionals; * GTZ: rural finance, commercial law development, revision of the Civil Code, registration of property rights over immovable property; * KFW: commercial bank skills development; support to small and medium enterprises; * Other Bilaterals: EU/TACIS (enterprise development, financial, policy and legal reform); OECF (financial and enterprise reform); USAID (banking skills development and judicial training); UNDP (restructuring of privatized enterprises); New Zealand (enterprise restructuring); Asia Foundation, Center for Institutional Reform and the Informal Sector (IRIS) (legal training), and the Netherlands, Denmark, Australia, Japan, and German NGOs (legal training).
 - 4 - TECHNICAL ANNEX Project Components A. Commercial Bank Institutional Development ($0.6 million) 8. This component is a highly targeted intervention to support long-term development of a single financial institution, as a follow-up to TA provided by other donors. This TA will focus particularly on building skills in loan accounting, loan workout and restructuring functions of the selected institution, as this has been identified as a priority area for external support. Further to a memorandum of understanding between the Government, IDA and ADB agreed in May 1996, ADB is taking the lead in policy discussion and provision of technical assistance in Mongolia's financial sector to facilitate bottom-up restructuring of the banking system. ADB has developed restructuring plans for the large commercial banks, and provided preliminary training in accountancy development to Ardyn and ITI banks. In parallel with its FSPL, ADB proposes to finance long-term advisory assistance and training for BOM's supervision department. This will cover financial statement analysis, principles of accounting and auditing, and exercise of authority under the recently-enacted Central Bank Law (October 1996). ADB also proposes to assist major commercial banks in loan recovery, credit and risk management, project appraisal, accounting and auditing, and development of operational strategies. In addition, KFW is proposing a program of skills development to three commercial banks to enable them to provide effective intermediation to small and medium enterprises. Bank Twinning Arrangement 9. Experience from several countries indicates that emerging banks may benefit considerably from developing financial, business and institutional relations with foreign banks integrated in international capital markets. This arrangement may also assist emerging banks in improving operational procedures through access to professional advice from banking professionals practicing in advanced market economies. Twinning arrangements are widely considered the most efficient and cost effective way to develop long-term institutional development programs in the banking sector. This component would finance the twinning, over an 18-month to 2-year period, of the Trade and Development Bank with a reputable foreign bank, with a provision for a possible continuing business relationship thereafter. T&D bank is a fully state-owned commercial bank, with three branches, and a total of 79 employees. It has the best financial position of Mongolia's large banks, with sufficient capital and liquidity to operate safely and efficiently. It would benefit substantially from long-term assistance in designing and implementing business plans and operational strategies, defining the roles and accountability of staff, and workflow. 10. The foreign bank would provide long-term advisory services and on-the-job training in strategic planning and implementation, organizational structure and network development, marketing plans and customer services, development of new products and services, credit management and loan workout, treasury and asset/liability management, internal audit, communications and effective use of human resources. Given the importance of transparent financial reporting, the foreign bank will also undertake to train
 - 5 - TECHNICAL ANNEX staff in general international bank accounting concepts and practices, preparation of appropriate manuals, use of general ledger systems, and systematic preparation of financial statements. Debt Workout Capacity-Building 11. A Debt Workout Unit (DWU) will be established in T&D bank to recover outstanding loans from UB carpet factory, Erdenet carpet factory, Domod carpet factory, and Eermel textile company. T&D bank is the sole creditor of these loans which amount to 74 percent of its total loans outstanding, and 30 percent of all nonperforming loans. The initial mandate of the DWU will be to recover the outstanding loans from these companies, through a combination of changes in the terms of repayment with or without concessions, sale of assets, and liquidation proceeds as partial satisfaction of the loan. Under the terms of the contract for the T&D bank twinning arrangement, short-term consultants will assist the DWU in maximizing the recovery on each troubled loan. The consultants will review the financial position of the selected enterprises to determine their ability to meet the new terms of the loan based on projected cash flows, profitability and other credit factors. Based on this analysis, T&D bank will initiate bankruptcy procedures and/or develop repayment schedules linked to enterprise performance, as appropriate. The objective of these initial workouts, in addition to loan recovery, is to create a core group of local experts that can replicate the restructuring/recovery exercise in the years to come. The DWU will continue its operations as a permanent department within T&D Bank, to provide a model for other debt workout units to be established in other commercial banks. Terms of Reference are in Annex 5. B. Public Enterprise Financial Restructuring ($0.2 million) 12. The Government's enterprise reform program, supported by BESAC, is being managed by the State Property Committee (SPC), a high-level independent body of Government, reporting to the Prime Minister. SPC has wide-ranging powers to initiate and oversee privatization, and public enterprise enterprise restructuring or liquidation as a respresentative of Government or dominant creditors. SPC will initiate workout exercises for two large politically-sensitive enterprises, the Bagahangai Meat Company and the Darkhan Mini-Metal Plant. These are among the largest defaulters to the banking system. Under this financial restructuring program, they will be isolated from all sources of financing except the budget which will finance limited working capital expenditures. A moratorium will be established on their debt-service obligations. SPC will carry out viability assessments and recommend liquidation or restructuring, to be implemented within an 18 month period. 13. BELTAC will finance two short-term advisors to assist SPC in preparing viability assessments, restructuring or liquidation plans and debt restructuring programs for these enterprises. Thereafter, the advisors would work with the companies to implement priority actions identified in the restructuring plan, and with SPC to prepare loan repayment schedules, so that the enterpriss can service their debts. The case of Darkhan mini-metal plant presents particular difficulties. The plant was financed by a $30 million
 -6 - TECHNICAL ANNEX commercial loan from Japan's EXIM Bank, guaranteed by the Government of Mongolia. This loan therefore represents a contingent liability on the budget. Japan is continuing to provide official development assistance to improve the plant's physical performance. C. Legal Reform Program ($1.2 million) 14. The Legal Reform Program consists of a series of subprojects, identified by local stakeholders as addressing priority areas of reform that require external assistance. The subprojects were designed and will be implemented by interinstitutional working groups, comprising representatives of the Ministry of Justice, Bank of Mongolia, Ministry of Finance, Supreme Court, Bureau of Foreign Investment, and commercial banks. Client ownership and continuing participation will remain essential for effective implementation of this component, given the broad-ranging and interinstitutional nature of proposed reforms and interventions. The subprojects also take into account the TA activities financed by ADB, GTZ and USAID, among others. The Program will be implemented in stages, based on an agreed annual work program. An initial pipeline of subprojects has reached an advanced stage of preparation (see paras 15-17). Further resources will be allocated to additional subprojects (see para 18), based on initial outcomes and performance indicators. All subproject proposals are subject to IDA's prior approval, on recommendation of the Steering Committee. Execution of Judgments 15. The objective of this subproject is to strengthen the operations of the Bailiffs Department under the MOJ with a view to improving enforcement of civil judgments. Current problems have resulted in a widespread lack of confidence in the court system, particularly on the part of banks. The subproject will finance a study tour to two foreign jurisdictions to familiarize Mongolian bailiffs with enforcement procedures and operations in other countries. On the basis of this study tour, recommendations for the improvement of the Bailiffs Department will be prepared and submitted to the Minister of Justice for implementation. In addition, a basic training course for bailiffs focusing among others on loan recovery will be designed and held at least once in Ulaanbaatar. The design of the course will emphasize sustainability by including a training of trainers module and ensuring that the course can be replicated throughout the country. Course design will be based on creative teaching methods including role playing and moot courts. Collateral Registration 16. Registration of property rights and secured interests facilitates and reduces the transaction cost of financial intermediation. A functioning and credible collateral system is essential to the long-term viability of commercial banking. A prefeasibility study (financed by IDA in 1996 under a Norwegian trust fund) has confirmed the complexity of the establishment/reform of such registers in Mongolia. A working group has been established to provide guidance on this subject. In view of GTZ's involvement in the registration of immovable property, the proposed subproject focuses on the registration of secured interests in movable property. A workshop will be held in Ulaanbaatar to review
 - 7 - TECHNICAL ANNEX all legal, technical and institutional issues involved, including the need for clear and transparent procedures regarding the taking, perfecting and foreclosure of collateral, as well as what is required to actually establish and operate a registry. Specific recommendations resulting from the workshop will be followed by the development and implementation of a business plan for the establishment of a registry for secured interests in movable property. IDA will finance foreign advisors, hard and software required for the establishment of the registry and training of operators. Insolvency 17. A revised insolvency law is under preparation. This process is being guided by a working group established for this purpose. A first draft has been prepared and reviewed by IDA. Submission of a revised draft to IDA for review is a Credit Effectiveness condition for BESAC. The Government expects to submit a draft law to Parliament for enactment during the 1997 fall session. The subproject focuses on training and a public information campaign to familiarize the public and legal professionals with enterprise restructuring and liquidation.. Training courses will be designed and held for trustees (a new concept introduced in the draft law) judges and other legal professionals likely to be involved in the implementation of the new insolvency law. Course design will promote sustainability by including a training for trainers module and will be based on creative teaching methods like role plays. The subproject will also finance part of a broader public information campaign that is being planned by the MOJ. Additional Subprojects 18. BELTAC would support additional subprojects identified by the Steering Committee based on evolving needs and priorities, and the availability of funds under this component.. In this regard, potential subprojects concern: (a) the development of model loan, collateral and guarantee documentation: (b) the training of legal professionals in the use of these documents and the application of relevant procedures; and (c) the training of legal professionals regarding the recently enacted banking laws. PROJECT ADMINISTRATION AND IMPLEMENTATION Project Cost and Financing 20. The total cost of the project is $2.3 million, of which $2.0 million is in foreign exchange. All costs have been subjected to price contingencies of 15 percent. The estimates for consulting assignments, studies and training are based on typical current costs for such assignments. The foreign exchange costs will be met by IDA. The local currency requirements ($0.3 million) would be met by the Borrower from its own resources and from available grant funding. Project Implementation and Reporting 21. The TA will be implemented over a two-and-a-half year period. Each component will be managed by a designated counterpart institution: (a) Commercial Bank Institutional Development--Trade and Development Bank; (b) Public Enterprise Financial Restructuring--SPC; and (c) Legal Reform Program-- Ministry of Justice, through the Legal Reform Project Unit. Each counterpart agency will make available competent staff in adequate numbers to be responsible for coordination and supervision of project implementation. Each counterpart agency will monitor procurement and disbursement under their component, and maintain records of all transactions, including supporting documents for statements of expenditure, in accordance with sound accounting practices acceptable to IDA. The counterpart agencies will submit quarterly progress reports in a format acceptable to IDA within two weeks from the end of each quarter. In addition, the counterpart agencies will submit a mid-term report on project implementation on or about December 31, 1998. This report will integrate the results of the quarterly reports and set out recommendations to ensure efficient implementation and achievement of project objectives thereafter. Reporting requirements for consultants will be specified in Terms of Reference. Legal Reform Program: Special Conditions for Project Implementation 22. MOJ will establish and maintain a Steering Committee composed of representatives of the public and private sector, including ministries of Finance and Justice, BOM and commercial banks. The Committee will meet at least on a quarterly basis to review component implementation. In addition, MOJ will establish a Legal Reform Project Unit for the duration of the project. This Unit will be staffed on a full-time basis by at least one lawyer and an administrative assistant, each with qualifications and
 - 10- TECHNICAL ANNEX experience acceptable to IDA. The Legal Reform Project Unit will be responsible for day- to-day management of this component, including preparation of annual work programs, design of new subprojects, liaising with local stakeholders and the local donor community. The Steering Committee and the Project Unit will be established prior to Board presentation. The Unit will be headed by a Program Coordinator; draft terms of reference are in Annex 4. The Unit will prepare subprojects for review by MOJ, the Steering Committee and IDA. 23. Individual subprojects will be prepared according to a standard format, and reviewed on the basis of the following criteria: purpose and scope, implementation method, and budgetary requirement. The standard format for preparation of proposals is based on the following core elements: (a) description of objectives; (b) analysis of key issues; (c) description of ongoing initiatives; (d) relevance to ongoing initiatives and overall project objectives; (e) implementation timetable; (f) cost breakdown, including foreign and local currency requirements; (g) description of expected benefits and strategy for monitoring progress, based on agreed indicators; and (h) confirmation of Steering Committee endorsement. Accounting and Auditing 24. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will be responsible for preparation of consolidated Project Accounts. All accounts will be audited within six months of the end of the fiscal year by independent auditors acceptable to IDA. MOF will retain all documentation for at least one year after receipt by IDA of the audit report for the year in which the last disbursement was made, and would make documents available for review by IDA supervision missions and external auditors. Procurement 25. Selection and appointment of consultants for technical assistance and support of project implementation will be carried out in accordance with IDA's Guidelines on Selection and Employment of Consultants by World Bank Borrowers, January 1997. All contracts for consultant services valued at $50,000 and above, and for all contracts with individuals, regardless of value, will be subject to IDA's prior review and approval. Contracts with firms valued at less than $50,000 will be subject to selective post award
 - 11 - TECHNICAL ANNEX reviews by IDA. Procurement of equipment will be made in accordance with the Guidelines for Procuirement under IBRD Loans and IDA Credits, published by the Bank in January 1995 and revised in January and August 1996. Procurement of equipment will be made through International Shopping. Equipment estimated to cost less than $50,000 per contract, up to an aggregate amount not exceeding $150,000, may be procured under contracts awarded on the basis of National Shopping. Disbursement 26. Disbursements will be restricted to the subcomponents outlined above, for advisory services and training (100 percent of expenditures), and limited quantities of related equipment and materials (100 percent of foreign expenditures, 100 percent of local expenditures--ex-factory cost- and 75 percent of local expenditures for other items procured locally). Disbursements will be made on the basis of documented disbursement applications, except for expenditures below $50,000 equivalent for goods, consulting services, study tours and workshops which will be based on statements of expenditure. These statements will indicate the services provided, invoice, customs declaration, and evidence of payment. 27. To facilitate project implementation, the Borrower will establish a Special Account in US dollars at a bank acceptable to IDA to cover IDA's share of eligible expenditures. The authorized allocation of this account would be $500,000 million equivalent. At the request of the Borrower and, based on project needs, IDA would make an initial deposit into the special account up to the amount of the authorized allocation. Applications for replenishment of the special account would be submitted quarterly, or when one third of the amount deposited has been withdrawn, whichever occurs earlier. Documentation requirements would follow the same procedure as described in para 26. In addition, monthly bank statements of the special account, reconciled by the Borrower, should accompany all replenishment requests.

The Government of Mongolia (GOM) has prepared a Banking, Enterprise and Legal Technical Assistance project for the implementation of which it has sought the financial assistance of the International Development Association (IDA). One of the project components is a Legal Reform Program. The objective of the Legal Reform Program is to strengthen the legal and regulatory environrment for banking and enterprise operations in Mongolia. The Legal Reform Program consists of the design and implementation of specific legal reform subprojects that focus on key problems in the legal environment. A Legal Diagnostic Study was carried out in 1995 to identify key problems in the legal environment and potential solutions. In December 1995 a two-day seminar was conducted to discuss the findings of the Study. 2. On the basis of recommendations made in the Study and the Seminar, the Government has developed a pipeline of subprojects to be financed under the Project. These subprojects focus on: (a) loan and guarantee documentation, (b) execution of judgments, (c) contractual defaults, (d) secured transactions, and (e) property and collateral registration. Implementation of these subprojects is likely to start in the first quarter of 1997. Further subprojects will be designed in the course of Project implementation based on evolving needs and priorities, and availability of funds. 3. The Legal Reform Program will be implemented through the Ministry of Justice (MOJ), and under the guidance of an interinstitutional and multidisciplinary steering committee (the Steering Committee). In addition, MOJ will establish a Legal Reform Project Unit under the aegis of the Ministry to coordinate all aspects of Project administration. The Legal Program Coordinator will be the head of this Unit. Scope of the assignment 4. The Legal Program Coordinator will be responsible for the day to day management of the Legal Reform Program, including: (a) preparing annual work programs; (b) acting as secretary to the Steering Committee; (c) establishing working groups involved in the design of additional subprojects;
 33 ANNEX 4 (d) liaising with local stakeholders; (e) designing legal reform subprojects; (f) preparing written subproject proposals for review by working groups, the Steering Committee and MIOJ; (g) submitting subproject proposals to IDA for approval; (h) recruiting consultants as wvell as the procuring equipment and materials in accordance with applicable procedures; (i) coordinating subproject implementation; (j) maintaining the accounts for the Legal Reform Program; (k) monitoring and reporting on the implementation of subprojects, and submitting quarterly reports to IDA and the Steering Committee; and (1) coordinating activities with the local donor community. Qualifications 5. The Legal Program Coordinator will possess a law degree from a recognized university, with experience of Mongolian law and judicial processes satisfactory to IDA. The successful candidate will have at least five years of postgraduate work experience in areas relevant to this assignment, including exposure to market economy legal systems. Furthermore, the successful candidate shall have good working knowledge of English (written and spoken).
 -34- ANNEX5 ANNEX 5: BANK TWINNING-TERMS OF REFERENCE Background 1. In order to ensure a rapid and efficient transition towards autonomous, competitive commercial banking in a market environment, the Government of Mongolia envisages that a program of technical assistance services would be provided by a reputable savings bank, under a contractual arrangement. referred to as a twinning arrangement, which could include a provision for an ongoing future commercial relationship between the selected local bank and the foreign bank. The foreign partner bank is hereinafter referred to as the Consultant . The local bank is referred to as the Trade and Development Bank (T&D Bank). 2. The Consultant will generally act in an advisory capacity, although line responsibilities may also be requested in some critical areas. e.g., treasury and debt workout. Training of counterpart staff wvill form an important part of the Consultant's duties. The Consultant should arrange for all services required by the T&D Bank under this program, although sub-contract arrangements may be entered into for the provision of certain specialized services. If this is done, the Consultant will supervise and be responsible for the adequacy and delivery of such services. 3. These terms of reference specify- the required results or deliverables of the work to be performed. The manner in which this work is conducted has not been prescribed. This is to allow for innovation in the design of the work program to meet the particular needs of T&D Bank in a cost-effective manner. 4. All proposals will be evaluated on the basis of the criteria defined in paras x-x, and the contract will be awarded according to standard Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by World Bank Borrowers and by the WVorld Bank as an Executing Agency, August 1981. Specific Areas for Institution Building 5. It is clear that the T&D Bank has several major institutional development needs. At this stage of the T&D Bank's development. it is important to identify the full range of its development needs and to set priorities. Therefore, the project will be conducted in two phases--(a) a diagnostic and planning phase (DPP), and (b) an implementation phase (IP). In parallel with the diagnostic and planning phase, the Consultants will provide
 -35- ANNEX5 urgent assistance in debt workout, to recover the largest non-performing loans from defaulting enterprises. Scope of Work 6. The diagnostic and planning phase will be conducted in about two months. It will in include: (a) a diagnostic review of the T&D Bank; (b) preparation of a preliminary strategic plan; (c) analysis of automation needs; (d) assessment of training needs; and (e) preparation of a detailed institutional development program (IDP). The implementation phase will continue for 18 months to two years. Diagnostic and Planning Plhase 7. The scope of work includes, but is not limited to the following tasks: (a) Diagnostic Review This should cover all major areas of the T&D Bank and focus on identifying major institutional development needs. The T&D Bank expects, inter alia, the following analyses and reviews: (i)Environmental analysis. Identification of the key aspects of the economic and business environment; financial conditions affecting customers; the regulatory and supervisory environment; legal and social constraints; and the immediate impact of and outlook in these areas; (ii)Financial Analysis. Analysis of the balance sheet; profit and loss statement; main costs and revenue stream; quality of the loan portfolio; liquidity and capital adequacy; branch network and profitability; and the intermediation cost(s) and pricing of main products and services; (iii)Market analysis. Identification and analvsis of the T&D Bank's market position and share; its strengths and weaknesses vis-a- vis the composition and size of the market and the market needs for banking services; (iv)Competitor analysis. Identification and analysis of the T&D Bank's competitive position; its strengths and wveaknesses vis-a-vis the composition, size of important competitors. both public and private, (v)Product and service analysis. An inventory of the T&D Bank's products and services; a broad assessment of their market attractiveness. competitiveness, and profitability:
 -36- ANNEX5 (vi)Organizational Review. A review and analysis of the organizational structure of the T&D Bank and the requirements for methods, processes and procedures, strategies, and realignments to effectively realize the T&D Bank's objective(s) and mandate. The review and analysis should take into account areas such as the T&D Bank's governance structure; the need for additional functions and interlinkages; the amalgamation of main functions; delegation and span of authority: clear definition of duties and responsibilities; and the relationships between head-office and the regional and branch offices; (vii)Management Review. A review and analysis of the adequacy of existing management processes (e.g., decision-making, communications and goal-setting), management staff qualifications, and recruitment, staffing, retrenchment, and human resource policies; (viii)Review of Planning, Budgeting and Performance Measurement Process. A review and analysis of the T&D Bank's procedures for planning, budgeting, and performance measures and monitoring. The long-term goal should be to establish such a process for the T&D Bank overall, for each staff unit, and each line unit; (ix) Review of Credit Policy, Procedures and Risk Management. A review and analysis of the policies and procedures required for the effective management of the entire credit process including loan origination, credit analysis and approval, loan servicing, and problem loan management. Particular attention should be paid to the existence of effective internal controls; procedures for assessing and dealing with credit risk; classification and aging of loans; provisioning for bad and doubtful debts; delegation of credit authority to the regional and branch levels; debt recovery; and credit management monitoring, and reporting. Recommendations should cover the establishment of a loan servicing and monitoring system for loan portfolio management including: loan repayments; loan classification and provisioning according to Bank of Mongolia (Central Bank) regulations and international standards; and arrears, delinquency, and loan liquidation management; (x) Review of Treasury Management. A review and appraisal of the effectiveness and adequacy of treasury management, including policies and procedures (and information and skills) for managing the T&D Bank's exposure to changes in interest rates; foreign exchange risk including trading limits; liquidity and financial management; maintenance of capital adequacy requirements; accounting and
 -37- ANNEX5 revaluation procedures; and portfolio maturity matching. Methods of establishing, reconciling and controlling foreign correspondent T&D Bank accounts should also be assessed. Particular attention should be paid to the T&D Bank s needs in effecting international settlements. The review should indicate areas for possible improvements in the T&D Bank's present policies and procedures; (xi) Review of Accounting and Management Information. A review and analysis of the existing accounting and management information systems, indicating areas for modifications and improvements. Accounting systems at the T&D Bank have been converted to adapted to International Accounting Standards (IAS); (xii)Operations Review. A review and analysis of the T&D Bank'soperational capacity and needs, controls and efficiency, paying particular attention to branch operations and inter-branch clearing; savings mobilization and lending; (xiii)Review of Training Needs and Human Resource Management. A review and analysis of the T&D Bank's specific skill needs for management, professional and technical, and key clerical and administrative positions. The T&D Bank's training and development infrastructure will be assessed and developed as well as key human resource management processes, and recruitment and staffing policies and procedures; and (xiv)Review of Internal Audit. A review and analysis of the internal controls and procedures, and the internal audit function, to determine their effectiveness in ensuring that the T&D Bank's assets are safeguarded; transactions are executed in accordance with management's directives, and transactions are adequately recorded to permit the timely preparation of the T&D Bank's financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. The review and analysis should indicate the need of the T&D Bank has a manual(s) or other documentation that incorporates sound audit policies and practical audit procedures, and the level of audit skills that need upgrading. (b) Preliminary Strategic Plan Although retail banking is its major activity, the T&D Bank is presently involved in a wider range of activities, including trade financing. Moreover, sound market opportunities from small and medium- sized enterprises. particularlv in privatizations and start-up operations, can provide an effective complement to its retail banking businesses. The
 -38- ANNEX5 Consultant will work with management to develop a preliminary strategy that defines: * The institutional vision of the T&D Bank * Financial objectives * Organizational and human resource development objectives * Target markets * Main products and services; and main distribution channels * Competitive positioning * Priority strategies and actions in its institutional strengthening and financial restructuring (particularly the institutional development actions) to meet its objectives * A corporate business plan that defines the strategies, incorporates realistic assumptions, identifies resource requirements, and projects financial outcomes. (c) Analysis of Automation Need~ Modifications in existing systems, including decision support software may be needed to support other changes or developments being called for in the strategic plan and the IDP. In addition, system development and installation priorities may need to be modified to ensure that maximum flexibility is built into the system to provide for additional applications and hardware at a later stage. (d) Assessment of Training Needs,The Consultant will conduct a training needs analysis of key jobs and functions within the structure of the Board of Directors and senior management, and professional, technical, clerical, and administrative ranks at all levels in the operations of the T&D Bank. The purpose of the training needs analysis will be to identify the specific priorities for training that the T&D Bank needs during and after the implementation phase (IP). (e) Institutional Development Program. Based on the diagnostic review, the strategic plan and any other relevant input, the Consultant will prepare an institutional developmentprogram (IDP) for the T&D Bank which will include: * The actions that must be taken to modernize the T&D Bank and execute its strategic plan; * Specific work plans and target completion for each action; * A prioritized sequence and schedule for the actions and their implementation, taking into consideration the organization's capacity to absorb the change(s); * An outline of the required financial, human, and administrative resources to carrv out the plan.
 -39- NN 8. Management Approval and Commitment The Consultant will be working closely with T&D Bank management during each module of the work in the diagnostic and planning phase. At the end of this phase. it will be necessary to secure formal approval of the institutional development plan from T&D Bank management and the Board of Directors, and their commitment to the plan. since the IDP will be the basis for extensive work in Phase II of the program. For that work to proceed expeditiously and for real changes to occur in the practices and operations of the T&D Bank, there has to be full support for that work from all concerned parties. Institutional Development Program Implementation Plhase (IP) 9. The work in this phase will be defined by the IDP, and includes, but is not limited to the following tasks during the next 10-16 months: * Developing a focus on the T&D Bank's corporate objectives consistent with its legal mandate and charter: - Initiating financial restructuring of the balance sheet; - Rationalizing the organizational and administrative structure of the T&D Bank, including reorganization, redundancy retrenchment, and restaffing; - Training in priority areas; • Implementing the credit and risk administration process; * Implementing the treasury and asset/liability management process; * Developing new products and price(s) of financial instruments and services; * Implementing the loan servicing operations including loan repayments, arrears, delinquency, and liquidation management, loan aging and provisioning, and capital recovery of non-performing assets; * Implementing the internal audit function; * Detailed automation planning and implementation for new functions (e.g., treasury management, the accounting system, etc.); * Implementing a comprehensive human resource management system; * Initiating selective improvements in marketing and customer service Debt Workout 10. Within the terms of the twinning contract, the Consultants will be required to designate staff to provide specialized assistance to T&D Bank s Debt Workout Unit (DWUJ), in resolving non-performing loans to four enterprises: the UB carpet factory, Erdenet carpet factory. Dornod carpet factory, and Eermel textile company. T&D Bank is the sole creditor of these loans. The objective is to develop repayment schedules and return these loans to accrual status. Thereafter, the Consultants will continue to train the staff of the unit in debt wvorkout procedures. as part of standard commercial bank credit and risk management. The scope of wvork for this assignment includes:
 - 40 - ANNEX S . Detailed review of relevant credit files, including related agreements between the Government and foreign creditor banks; * Evaluation of debt workout options, including: revision of payment schedules; modification of interest rates, principal amounts or accrued interest; transfer of property or other collateral to T&D Bank in full or partial satisfaction for the debt; . Establishment of procedures for accurate and systematic reporting of troubled loans to enable bank management to understand fully the effects that such loans have on the bank's financial condition and results of operations; Implementation of debt workout strategies for the four enterprises; . On-the-job training of DWU staff, and staff of other commercial banks, if requested; Reporting Requirements 12. The Consultant is asked to submit a detailed technical and financial proposal on the diagnostic and planning phase (DPP) of the work (for approximately two months duration), and a general proposal on the first six months of the implementation phase (IP), covering the areas that would likely be achieved during the period. The exact content of the first 6 months of the implementation phase will be decided at the end of Phase 1. 13. In the second stage of the implementation phase, it is anticipated that the continuation of the work in many of the areas covered in the first stage will include the following tasks: Development of the management information system; . Implementation of a planning, budgeting, and performance measuring process and system; Refinement of marketing techniques; Development of the internal auditing system; * Refinement of the strategic plan. 14. During the implementation phase. the relationship between the T&D Bank and the Government might progressively evolve into a more commercial mode. Time Frame and Completion Schedule 15. The Consultant is expected to start the work within four weeks of the execution of the contract. The Diagnostic Phase will be completed two months thereafter. The Implementation Phase will end no later than 24 months thereafter.
 -41- ANNEX5 Training Requirements 16. The Consultant is expected to provide on-the-job-training for the T&D Bank's counterpart staff in four diagnostic and planning areas: * Diagnostic review * Strategic planning . Automation planning * Training needs analysis. 17. In the first 6 months of the IP, the Consultant is expected to train a core group of managers and staff utilizing the new and upgraded processes that have been developed, such as: . Savings administration * Credit management * Debt Workout • Treasury and asset/liability management * Accounting, auditing, and financial reporting * Product and service development and pricing * Operations and branch banking * Technical assistance and training, and program development * Human resource management. Requirements from the Consultant 18. Technical Proposal The Consultant must put forward a technical proposal which covers all the areas of technical assistance included in this Terms of Reference. The Consultant must include profile data including, at a minimum, the following information: * Name, address, contact details; * Relevant experience in relation to the tasks specified in the Terms of Reference, including experience in countries with banking systems similar to Mongolia; * Relevant experience of team members to be assigned to the work; * Detailed CVs of all staff proposed for the assignment; specify any Russian language capabilities; * Nature of the respondent's institution and profile of operations; extent of foreign operations; * Total assets, net assets, net profits over the last three years (an annual report might meet the above two requirements); * Current and planned linkages to Mongolian banks; * Reasons for tendering for the assignment.
 - 42- ANNEX 5 19. The timing and manner in which the assistance is to be provided is to be clearly explained. The Consultant's work plan should clearly indicate: * The work to be performed by long-term Consultants in staff-weeks; * The work to be performed by short-term Consultants in staff-weeks * Work being performed outside Mongolia; * Materials to be made available to T&D Bank staff; * Training to be provided; * Full details on the background and proposed role of any sub-contractors is to be specified. 20. Financial Proposal A separate financial proposal must be prepared. This will include the detailed work plan. Each major component of the work is to be priced separately. The proposal must include all costs, excluding some local costs which may, by agreement, be covered by the T&D Bank. Any costs assumed to be covered in this way must be clearly identified in the proposal. Resources Available to the Consultant 21. The following resources will be made available to the Consultant on the basis of the program of work agreed with the T&D Bank: * The T&D Bank's data, policies and procedures; * At least one interpreter for each three members of the Consultant's staff; * Document translation facilities; * Secretarial assistance and report production facilities; * Separate office and telephone for each Consultant; * At least one full-time qualified counterpart for each module of work Evaluation Criteria 22. Proposals will be evaluated bv a committee which is expected to consist of representatives of T&D Bank, Bank of Mongolia and the Ministry of Finance. Bidding firms will provide their technical and financial proposals in different envelopes. The proposals will be evaluated on technical and financial considerations. Technical proposals will be rated as follows: * Experience of the respondent in similar assignments and familiarity with
 - 43 - ANNEX5 transitional economies in Eastern Europe or former Soviet Republics 10 * Experience of the respondent in the savings bank sector 15 * Experience of the team members in similar assignments 15 * Team members' qualifications and experience in functional areas to which assigned in the project 30 * Suitability of the proposed approach 20 * Language capabilities of proposed staff (Russian and English desirable) 10 Total 100 23. The criteria relevant for selecting prospective twinning partners include: * strong interest by the prospective twinning partner in the proposed twinning arrangement; * building and maintenance of strong institutional relationship with T&D Bank beyond the term of the twinning arrangement; * in-depth experience by the prospective twinning partner in institutional building under twinning arrangements in other technical assistance programs; * prospective twinning partner s involvement in the main lines of business of T&D Bank, and also in the lines of business the recipient bank is likely to enter into; and * proximity of the prospective twinning partner to Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia to reduce travel costs.

doc.abstracts: The objectives of the Banking, Enterprise and Legal Technical Assistance Credit Project (BELTAC) are two-fold. The immediate objective is to facilitate the project's implementation, in particular, the debt workout and loan recovery elements of the government's reform program. The longer-term objective is to promote institutional and skills development to sustain the reforms implemented under the parallel project, the Banking and Enterprise Sector Adjustment Credit (BESAC). BELTAC's components are: (1) commercial bank institutional development, a twinning arrangement of the T & D Bank with a reputable foreign bank, with special attention given to advisory assistance and training for debt workout capacity building, and advisors to help assess the banking institution viability; (2) public enterprise financial restructuring aided by four short-term advisors financed to help carry out financial viability assessments for the two largest public enterprise defaulters; and (3) a legal reform program based on a pipeline of subprojects covering (a) the execution of judgments, specifically, strengthening the Bailiff's office; (b) the establishment of a collateral registry for movable property to facilitate collateralized lending; and (c) a public information campaign focusing on enterprise restructuring and liquidation, and training of legal professionals.
